issue.title: Crash on macOS with SpawnNewInstance action
issue.body:
This has been introduced by https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/pull/1971.

It has already been accepted in #1979 that implementing this feature on Windows takes significantly more effort than on Linux, so it's not fully supported initially.

For macOS this feature has been enabled, but it currently leads to a crash whenever it is used. It should be investigated if this can be easily fixed to achieve feature parity with Linux, otherwise it should be disabled on macOS, similar to the current Windows implementation.

issue.title: [WIP] Fix crash on macOS and BSD for spawn_new_instance action
issue.body:
Currently spawn new instance action is crashing on macOS and BSD systems. This pull request tries to fix the crash and implement a way to get the current working directory of the child shell for this 2 systems. See #1988

This was implemented blindly. I'm not sure if it works since I have no macOs or BSD machine to test it.  ```libproc-rs ``` was used to get the current working directory for macOS.
For BSD, it parses the output from ```procstat -f $PID ```command. 

I would like macOS and BSD to test this changes.

This fixes https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1988.

issue.title: Windows: Cannot spawn new "cmd" instance using "command" keybinding
issue.body:
On windows if I add the following keybind:

      - { key: T,        mods: Control|Shift, command: {program: "cmd", args: []} }

Then when I hit Ctrl+Shift+T, the following happens:

- If the `Alacritty` instance running was launched from the desktop or taskbar, the `cmd` window immediately crashes.
- If the `Alacritty` instance was launched from another terminal, then that terminal is taken over by the new `cmd` process (wat!)

The fault all seems to lie in the `spawn_daemon` function. I think to fix we would need to use windows APIs directly rather than `std::process::Command`, which is a bit sad.

I will write up a PR, but I wanted to survey opinion first on what "correct" behaviour of this keybind should be. I propose the following:

Keybind | Result
------------ | -------------
`{program: "cmd", args: []}` | New command window opens
`{program: "cmd", args: ["echo", "hello"]}`| New command window opens, prints hello, immediately closes.
`{program: "foo", args: []}`| Program "foo" opens in new window

In particular, in Linux daemons as I understand are background processes. So should there be any situations where I can spawn a process with a hidden console window?

I discovered this while digging around with solving #1979. The `cmd.exe` pseudoconsole immediately crashes with the conpty backend.

body: I've been looking into this a little tonight for Windows. It seems really hard to do it reliably - most robust suggestions I can find involve using low level windows APIs: `CreateRemoteThread` to inject a DLL into the child cmd.exe process and from that DLL execute `GetCurrentDirectory` and send the result back to Alacritty. Seems awfully complicated. There's probably a better solution than that somewhere.

issue.title: Implement handling for OS escape code 7
issue.body:
This OS escape code is used by libvte (on unix) and Terminal.app on macOS to inform the terminal emulator about the working directory.

By adding an OSC 7 message to the prompt (i.e. as libvte and Terminal.app do) Alacritty can be updated about the working directory of a child process, even on Windows. This technique also works for subshells, e.g. 

    Alacritty -> bash -> bash

Checking `/proc` can only get the cwd of the "root" bash instance which Alacritty itself spawned, but this OSC 7 message can work for any depth of subshell as long as that subshell is sending the message (normally as part of its prompt).

Relevant iterm2 issue where they added support: https://gitlab.com/gnachman/iterm2/issues/3939
The Windows Terminal guys are also considering handling this: https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/issues/3158

So in theory, this has the potential to fix #1979 for all platforms without `/proc`, but requires the user to customise their prompt a little. If you are in favour of merging this PR, I will add documentation for customising the prompt.

Fixes #1979.

body:
@davidhewitt, @chrisduerr It seems that `CreateRemoteThread` trick is a lot more complex than just running `GetCurrentDirectory`, since the handler that starts the thread has to be in target process address space. For `cmd.exe`/`powershell.exe` that would be limited to WinAPI functions. So the actual code solution would be:
- Have a DLL on Windows that can be loaded into `cmd.exe` process that, when [initialising](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/dlls/dynamic-link-library-entry-point-function) runs `GetCurrentDirectory` and sends a message back to Alacritty process
- Allacritty, after `cmd.exe` has started, runs `CreateRemoteThread` with a handler that would run [`LoadLibrary`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/libloaderapi/nf-libloaderapi-loadlibrarya) with that DLL path

Overall the entire process sounds very iffy and error prone and can potentially trigger some AV scanners.

There is also an [alternative hack](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14018280/how-to-get-a-process-working-dir-on-windows) where by reading a specific section of process memory it is possible to get its cwd. There is a C# version somewhere that works for both 32b and 64b systems but both use [`NtQueryInformationProcess`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/winternl/nf-winternl-ntqueryinformationprocess?redirectedfrom=MSDN) that is considered a private WinAPI method.

There might be something specific to `conhost.exe` that could potentially be used, but so far I haven't found a nice way of doing that, so while also not ideal, @davidhewitt solution might be the most practical solution to the problem.

Thanks @cfiet. As well as being a hacky solution, `cargo install` doesn't deploy DLLs (as far as I'm aware) and it would create a whole pile of platform-specific code. And possible AV scanner issues so you point out. So I'm really not fond of the DLL approach.

You might be interested in #2937 which would create a simple cross-platform solution that's already implemented in some other terminal emulators. It would probably require you to opt in by modifying your `cmd.exe` prompt. I'd hope that maybe one day `powershell` would support it natively.

At the moment #2937 is blocked on some specification questions. The discussion is all on that thread.
Yeah, this will be resolved with #2937, I don't think there's any interest in finding alternative solutions for Windows/macOS/BSD at the moment.

For macOS this is fairly easy to resolve with the `proc_pidinfo` system call. Using the `tcgetpgrp` call also gives a relatively reliable way to determine which process should be queried, which exists on all Unix platforms in some way afaik.

So I think the best option is to just go ahead with implementing that on Unix and blame Windows for not supporting the necessary kernel functionality here.
